question.content: (b) Ataur Rahman Khan (c) Muhammad Habibur Rahman (d) Sheikh Hasina

solution.content: Sheikh Mujibur Rahman (First President of Bangladesh). Bangladesh: First Prime Minister Tajuddin Ahmad. First female prime minister Khaleda Zia. Personalities and their nicknames Grand Old man of India (Dadabhai Naoroji), Indian Einstein (Nagarjuna), Man of Peace (Lal Bahadur Shastri), Morning Star of India Renaissance (Raja Ram Mohan Roy), Machiavelli of India (Chanakya), Bengal Kesari (Ashutosh Mukherji).

question.content: Soparrkar and the logo of his worldwide initiative 'Dance for a Cause are being printed on an official postage stamp issued by the government.

solution.content: Bhutan. In 2008 Sandip Soparrkar had launched his Initiative Dance for a Cause at the World Economic forum in Davos, Switzerland. The First Stamp of Independent India was issued on 21 November 1947. It depicts the Indian Flag with the patriots' slogan, Jai Hind. The first postal stamp in India was introduced on 1 July 1852 under the Governor General Lord Dalhousie.

question.content: 'Mandarin' is the official language of which neighbouring country of India?

solution.content: China.

question.content: Which of the following is the official language of Afghanistan?
Who is known as the 'Father of Bangladesh' from the following options?

solution.content: Dari. Countries and Official Languages: China (Mandarin), France (French), Brazil (Portuguese), Mexico (Spanish), Saudi Arabia (Arabic), Myanmar (Burmese), Bangladesh (Bengali), Brunei (Malay), Cambodia (Khmer), Croatia (Croatian), Sri Lanka (Sinhala), Bhutan (Dzongkha).

question.content: Which religion has the maximum number of followers in Bhutan?

solution.content: Buddhism. Other religions in Bhutan: 2nd largest religion in Bhutan Hinduism followed by Christianity. Religions in India:

question.content: Which of the following ethnic groups are the largest in Myanmar?

solution.content: Bamar. Myanmar ethnic groups Karen, Shan, Mon, Chin, Kachin, Rohingya, Rakhine. Other largest Ethnic Groups: Punjabis - Pakistan, Pashtuns Afghanistan, Yamato - Japan, Inuit- Greenland, Khalkh - Mongolia, Bantu - Central, East and Southern Africa, Han- China.

question.content: Which is the national fruit of Bangladesh?

solution.content: Jackfruit. National fruits and Countries: India (Mango), Nepal (Raspberry), Saudi Arabia (Dates), Serbia (Plum), Singapore (Durian), Ukraine (cherry), Vietnam (Dragon fruit), Canada (Blueberries), Afghanistan (Pomegranate), New Zealand (Kiwifruit), Pakistan (Mango Summer and Guava Winter).

question.content: Which of the following cities of Nepal does NOT have a branch of 'Indian Citizens Association of Nepal'?

solution.content: Lalitpur. An Indian Citizens Association (ICA) of Nepal was formed on 14 September 1990. The Swami Vivekananda Centre for Indian Culture was set up in Kathmandu in 2008 to showcase the best of Indian culture. The Nepal-Bharat Library was founded in 1951 in Kathmandu. The India-Nepal Treaty of Peace and Friendship of 1950 forms the bedrock of the special relations that exist between India and Nepal.

question.content: According to the World Meteorological Organization report reviewed during 2010-2012, the highest registered shade temperature of was recorded at Al Aziziyah, Libya.

solution.content: 58°C. WMO (World Meteorological Organization): Formation - 23 March 1950, Headquarters - Geneva, Switzerland.

question.content: One of the major hubs of information technology is Silicon valley. which is situated in _

solution.content: California. Silicon Valley is the biggest hub of the IT industry in the world (Presence of biggest technology companies). Silicon valley of India Bengaluru.

question.content: Which continent of the world is referred to as a "Continent, Dedicated to Science"?

solution.content: Antarctica (the southernmost continent) It is the only continent with no permanent human habitation. There are 7 continents in the world: Asia, Europe, Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica and Australia. India is located in the southern part of the Asian continent.

question.content: What is the national sport of Bhutan?

solution.content: Archery - It is a game of shooting arrows using a bow. Related facts regarding Bhutan:- Capital (Thimphu), National flower (Blue poppy), National Tree (Himalayan cypress), National animal (the takin), National Anthem (Druk Tsendhen). National sports of other countries Cricket (Australia, England, Jamaica, Barbados), Volleyball (Sri Lanka and Nepal) and Ice Hockey (Canada).

question.content: What is the official language of Bhutan, a neighbouring country of India?

solution.content: Dzongkha (Tibetan script). Facts about Bhutan - Capital (Thimphu), Currency (Ngultrum or BTN), Borderline (699 km), Bordering states (Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Sikkim, and West Bengal).

question.content: Which country is the leading producer of jute?

solution.content: India is the largest producer of jute (golden fiber) in the world followed by Bangladesh, China, and Thailand. West Bengal followed by Bihar, Assam, Orissa, Andhra Pradesh, Tripura, and Meghalaya are the largest producers in India.

question.content: Techniques of making silk were first invented in China around_ years ago.

solution.content: 7000. The production of silk originated in Neolithic China {Yangshao culture (4th millennium BCE)). Silk is a natural protein fiber (fibroin). Highest silk-producing country - China. Karnataka (highest producer state of silk). The best-known silk is obtained from the cocoons of the larvae of the mulberry silkworm Bombyx mori reared in captivity (sericulture).

question.content: Which of the following neighbours of India has the highest population density?

solution.content: Bangladesh. According to the United Nations Department of Economics and Social Affairs (UN DESA), India overtakes China as the world's most populous country (As of April 2023).

question.content: Before being renamed, Mount Everest was simply known as_

solution.content: Peak XV. Mount Everest is a peak in the Himalayan mountain range. It is located between Nepal and Tibet. The mountain was named after George Everest, a former Surveyor General of India. The Tibetan name is Chomolungma, which means "Mother Goddess of the World." The Nepali name is Sagarmatha. In 1953 Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay were the first persons to climb Mount Everest.

question.content: The town of Paro is a famous tourist destination of _

solution.content: Bhutan. Paro is a valley town in Bhutan, west of the capital, Thimphu. This town is famous for its Druk Choeding temple which was built by Ngawang Chogyel, the prince-abbots of Ralung in Tibet in 1525.

question.content: In which of the following neighbouring countries of India is the famous Katas Raj Temples complex, with shrines of multiple faiths, located?

solution.content: Pakistan. Katas Raj has a collection of buildings and ruins that stretch in an unbroken line from the Buddhist era down to British rule.

question.content: In which of the following years was ADB (Asian Development Bank) established?

solution.content: 1966. Asian Development Bank (ADB) Headquarters: Manila, Philippines.

question.content: A gold lion passenger holding a sword in its right forepaw, is the national symbol of_

solution.content: Sri Lanka. The Sinha Flag or Lion Flag consists of a golden lion holding a kastane sword in its right fore-paw in a maroon background with four gold box leaves, one in each corner.

question.content: The international agreement Montreal Protocol is related to:

solution.content: Ozone Layer. Montreal Protocol is an international agreement made in 1987. It was designed to stop the production and import of ozone -depleting substances and reduce their concentration in the atmosphere to help protect the earth's ozone layer.

question.content: Which one of the following was the last imperial dynasty to rule China?

solution.content: Qing dynasty or the Qing Empire, officially the Great Qing. It was established in 1636 and ruled China from 1644 to 1912.

question.content: In which year was Bank of Bhutan Limited, the oldest bank of Bhutan, established?

solution.content: 1968. Bank of Bhutan (BoB) was established by a Royal Charter. Bhutan is a landlocked country in South Asia and its capital is Thimphu.

question.content: New Development Bank (NDB) is a multilateral development bank established in 2014. How many countries are members of NDB?

solution.content: 5. The five founding members of the New Development Bank include Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa. Headquarters: Shanghai, China.

question.content: In which year did Gongsa Ugyen Wangchuck become the first monarch of Bhutan?

solution.content: 1907. Ugyen Wangchuck was the first Druk Gyalpo (King of Bhutan) from 1907 to 1926.

question.content: Bangladesh was a part of Pakistan from

solution.content: 1947 - 1971. 26 March is celebrated as the Independence Day of Bangladesh.

question.content: Which one of the following is the largest valley in Asia?

solution.content: Dang valley. It lies between the Mahabharat Range in the north and the Churia Range in the south.

question.content: In the context of the Sri Lankan Civil War, what does the first 'T' in LTTE stand for?

solution.content: Tigers. LTTE stands for The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. LTTE was a military separatist group fighting for an independent homeland for Hindu Tamils in Northeastern Sri Lanka.

question.content: Which is the largest uranium producing country in the world?

solution.content: Kazakhstan. About two-thirds of the world's production of uranium from mines is from Kazakhstan, Canada and Australia.

question.content: Tummalapalle, believed to have one of the largest uranium reserves in the world, is situated in which of the following states?

solution.content: Andhra Pradesh. The Tummalapalle Mine is a uranium mine in Tummalapalli village located in Kadapa of the Indian state of Andhra Pradesh.

question.content: New Delhi's Lotus Temple was designed by an architect from

solution.content: Iran. The Bahai Lotus temple (1986) in New Delhi was designed by Iranian architect Fariborz Sahba in the shape of a lotus as it is common to several religions including Hinduism and Buddhism.

question.content: Which of the following is the second largest artificial lake in Asia?

solution.content: Dhebar Lake in Rajasthan. Miyun Reservoir is the largest artificial lake in Asia.

question.content: In Vienna, there's a statue of an Indian hockey player_ holding four hockey sticks in four Hands.

solution.content: Dhyan Chand. The statue indicates his control and mastery over the ball. Major Dhyan Chand was born on 29 August 1905 in Prayagraj (Allahabad), Uttar Pradesh. He represented India in the 1928, 1932, and 1936 Olympics and won gold medals in each Olympics. His autobiography 'Goal' was published in 1952 and was awarded India's third highest civilian award - Padma Bhushan in 1956.

question.content: _is the largest city in Sri Lanka

solution.content: Colombo. Kandy: The home of the Temple of the Tooth Relic, one of the most sacred places of worship in the Buddhist world.

question.content: 'Kiribath' is a rice dish from

solution.content: Sri Lanka. Popular foods in Sri Lanka- Kottu, Lamprais, Pol sambol, Puttu.

question.content: The _ in China is the world's longest man-made waterway.

solution.content: Grand Canal. The waterway is the link of the Yellow river and Yangtze River.
